title: IPO market has begun pushing back on growth-at-all-costs private companies
text:
Endeavor Group Holdings on Thursday became the latest company to scale back plans for an initial public offering, reducing the size of its planned deal and slashing the anticipated share-price range.

The move came as Peloton Interactive Inc.’s stock PTON, -11.17% struggled in its trading debut, and after We Co. WE, +0.00% , the parent of the office-space company WeWork, postponed its IPO and forced its chief executive to step down amid mounting concern about its huge losses and high leverage.

“The IPO window is closing on growth-at-all-costs, highly valued private companies that are trying to come to market with excessively valued pricing,” said Kathleen Smith, principal at Renaissance Capital, a provider of institutional research and IPO exchange-traded funds.

Endeavor EDR, +0.00% , an entertainment powerhouse that also owns sports and modeling agency IMG and mixed-martial-arts organization UFC, among other properties, said it now plans to offer just 15 million shares priced at $26 to $27 each, down from 19.4 million shares priced at $30 to $32 each in a filing on Sept. 16.

The company would raise $480 million at the top of that range, with proceeds earmarked for the repayment of debt and for working capital and general corporate purposes. Goldman Sachs, KKR, J.P. Morgan, Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank Securities are lead underwriters on the deal.

See: Peloton IPO: 5 things to know about the interactive exercise-machine company

Don’t miss: Entertainment giant Endeavor is going public: 5 things to know ahead of its IPO

Smith said she expects the company to complete the deal, given that it is profitable and has a track record of putting together media properties and talent, but conceded investors are sensitive about overpaying in the current market. “It’s called price discovery, and it’s a cleansing process that will make for better days ahead,” she said.

China’s Wanda Sports Group Co. Ltd. WSG, -0.69% , which is viewed as an Endeavor comparable, had a difficult IPO in July, when it priced a downsized deal at $8 a share, about double where it is trading today, said Smith.

“We know the market has been jittery and IPOs in general are seeing multiple contraction,” she said, citing recent pullbacks in Zoom Video Communications ZM, +0.19% , streaming platform Roku ROKU, -2.78% and cybersecuritiy company CrowdStrike as examples. CrowdStrike CRWD, -6.00% , which went public in June, has a one-month negative return of 30%, she said.

“Even the IPO ETF has had a pullback related to this,” she said. “Any company looking to go public and their underwriters should be looking at that.”

See now: Peloton’s bikes are expensive. So is its stock.

WeWork said earlier this week that co-founder and Chief Executive Adam Neumann is resigning from that role, amid mounting concerns from some of the company’s big investors about huge losses and liabilities. The company has inevitably been compared with Uber UBER, -0.35% and Lyft LYFT, +0.29% , the ride-sharing giants that went public this year in deals widely viewed as flops.

“Softbank’s Vision fund has invested in many highfliers such as Uber, WeWork and Slack,” said Per Roman, co-founder and managing partner of boutique investment bank GP Bullhound.

Don’t miss: WeWork is going public: 5 things to know about the office-sharing company

Those companies relied on increasingly extravagant funding rounds that came at higher and higher valuations: “land grabs fueled by venture capital,” he said.

Read also: Uber stock is a buy-one-get-one-free deal, analyst contends

Even Oracle ORCL, +0.22% founder and Executive Chairman Larry Ellison has criticized the trend, describing Uber and Lyft as “almost worthless” at a September event in San Francisco, as MarketWatch sister publication Barron’s reported.

The Renaissance IPO ETF IPO, -0.79% has fallen about 7% in the last three months but remains higher by 23% on the year, outpacing the S&P 500’s SPX, -0.24% 18% gain and the Dow Jones Industrial Average’s DJIA, -0.30% 15% rise.
